hints_html:
To compute the tangent line at a point, what important concept in this course do we need to utilize?

You will need to compute the derivative (which is the slope of the tangent line to the curve at a point). This can be done using the quotient rule.

Don’t forget to find the y value of the point, plug in the x coordinate into the original equation.
hints_latex:
To compute the tangent line at a point, what important concept in this
course do we need to utilize?

You will need to compute the derivative (which is the slope of the
tangent line to the curve at a point). This can be done using the
quotient rule.

Don't forget to find the \emph{y} value of the point, plug in the
\emph{x} coordinate into the original equation.
hints_raw:
To compute the tangent line at a point, what important concept in this course do we need to utilize?
You will need to compute the derivative (which is the slope of the tangent line to the curve at a point). This can be done using the quotient rule.
Don't forget to find the ''y'' value of the point, plug in the ''x'' coordinate into the original equation.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
To find the equation of the tangent line, we need to find the slope via the derivative. We can either apply the quotient rule or the power rule (by recognising \(y = \tan(x)^{-1}\). Using the quotient rule:

\[\begin{aligned} u(x) &= \cos(x) & u'(x) = -\sin(x)\\ v(x) &= \sin(x) & v'(x) = \cos(x)\end{aligned}\]

This gives:

\[\begin{aligned} {\frac{{\rm d} {y}}{{\rm d}x}} &= \frac{v u' - u v'}{v^2}\\ &= \frac{\sin(x) \cdot (-\sin(x) - \cos(x) \cdot \cos(x)}{[\sin(x)]^2}\\ &= \frac{- \sin^2(x) - \cos^2(x) }{\sin^2(x)}\\ &= \frac{- \left( \sin^2(x) + \cos^2(x)\right) }{\sin^2(x)}\\ &= \frac{-1}{\sin^2(x)}\end{aligned}\]

At \(x =\frac{5\pi}{3}\), we have \(\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\) (from part (a)), and so that means that the slope of the curve at \(x =\frac{5\pi}{3}\) is

\[\begin{aligned} y' &= \frac{-1}{\sin^2\left(x\right)}\\ &= \frac{-1}{\sin^2\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)}\\ &= \frac{-1}{\left[-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right]^2}\\ &= \frac{-1}{\frac{3}{4}}\\ &= \frac{-4}{3}\end{aligned}\]

We will also need the \(y\)-value at the point

\[\begin{aligned} y &= \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}\\ &= \frac{1}{\tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)}\\ &= \frac{1}{\tan\left(\frac{2\pi}{3}\right)}\\ &= \frac{1}{-\sqrt{3}}\\ &= -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}\end{aligned}\]

(here we used the fact that the function \(\displaystyle \tan(x)\) is \(\pi\) periodic and then applied the computation from part (a)).

This means our tangent line is:

\(y = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} - \frac{4}{3}\left(x - \frac{5\pi}{3}\right)\)
sols_latex:
To find the equation of the tangent line, we need to find the slope via
the derivative. We can either apply the quotient rule or the power rule
(by recognising $y = \tan(x)^{-1}$. Using the quotient rule:

\begin{align*}
u(x) &= \cos(x) & u'(x) = -\sin(x)\\
v(x) &= \sin(x) & v'(x) = \cos(x)
\end{align*}

This gives:

\begin{align*}
{\frac{{\rm d} {y}}{{\rm d}x}} &= \frac{v u' - u v'}{v^2}\\
&= \frac{\sin(x) \cdot (-\sin(x) - \cos(x) \cdot \cos(x)}{[\sin(x)]^2}\\
&= \frac{- \sin^2(x) - \cos^2(x) }{\sin^2(x)}\\
&= \frac{- \left( \sin^2(x) + \cos^2(x)\right) }{\sin^2(x)}\\
&= \frac{-1}{\sin^2(x)}
\end{align*}

At $x =\frac{5\pi}{3}$, we have
$\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ (from part (a)),
and so that means that the slope of the curve at $x =\frac{5\pi}{3}$ is

\begin{align*}
y' &= \frac{-1}{\sin^2\left(x\right)}\\
&= \frac{-1}{\sin^2\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)}\\
&= \frac{-1}{\left[-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right]^2}\\
&= \frac{-1}{\frac{3}{4}}\\
&= \frac{-4}{3}
\end{align*}

We will also need the $y$-value at the point

\begin{align*}
y &= \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}\\
&= \frac{1}{\tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)}\\
&= \frac{1}{\tan\left(\frac{2\pi}{3}\right)}\\
&= \frac{1}{-\sqrt{3}}\\
&= -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}
\end{align*}

(here we used the fact that the function $\displaystyle \tan(x)$ is
$\pi$ periodic and then applied the computation from part (a)).

This means our tangent line is:

$y = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} - \frac{4}{3}\left(x - \frac{5\pi}{3}\right)$
sols_raw:
To find the equation of the tangent line, we need to find the slope via the derivative. We can either apply the quotient rule or the power rule (by recognising <math>y = \tan(x)^{-1}</math>. Using the quotient rule:

<math>\begin{align}
u(x) &= \cos(x) & u'(x) = -\sin(x)\\
v(x) &= \sin(x) & v'(x) = \cos(x)\end{align}</math>

This gives:

<math>\begin{align}
{\frac{{\rm d} {y}}{{\rm d}x}} &= \frac{v u' - u v'}{v^2}\\
&= \frac{\sin(x) \cdot (-\sin(x) - \cos(x) \cdot \cos(x)}{[\sin(x)]^2}\\
&= \frac{- \sin^2(x) - \cos^2(x) }{\sin^2(x)}\\
&= \frac{- \left( \sin^2(x) + \cos^2(x)\right) }{\sin^2(x)}\\
&= \frac{-1}{\sin^2(x)}\\\end{align}</math>

At <math>x =\frac{5\pi}{3}</math>, we have <math>\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}</math> (from part (a)), and so that means that the slope of the curve at <math>x =\frac{5\pi}{3}</math> is

<math>\begin{align}
y' &= \frac{-1}{\sin^2\left(x\right)}\\
&= \frac{-1}{\sin^2\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)}\\
&= \frac{-1}{\left[-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right]^2}\\
&= \frac{-1}{\frac{3}{4}}\\
&= \frac{-4}{3}\\\end{align}</math>

We will also need the <math>y</math>-value at the point

<math>\begin{align}
y &= \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}\\
&= \frac{1}{\tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)}\\
&= \frac{1}{\tan\left(\frac{2\pi}{3}\right)}\\
&= \frac{1}{-\sqrt{3}}\\
&= -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}\end{align}</math>

(here we used the fact that the function <math> \displaystyle \tan(x) </math> is <math> \pi </math> periodic and then applied the computation from part (a)).

This means our tangent line is:

<math>y = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} - \frac{4}{3}\left(x - \frac{5\pi}{3}\right)</math>
statement_html: Find the equation of the line tangent to the curve \(y=\dfrac{\cos x}{\sin x}\) at \(x=\dfrac{5\pi}{3}\).
statement_latex:
Find the equation of the line tangent to the curve
$y=\dfrac{\cos x}{\sin x}$ at $x=\dfrac{5\pi}{3}$.
statement_raw: Find the equation of the line tangent to the curve <math>y=\dfrac{\cos x}{\sin x}</math> at <math>x=\dfrac{5\pi}{3}</math>.
